question: Let $z \in C$ with $\operatorname{Im}(z)=10$ and it satisfies $\frac{2 z-n}{2 z+n}=2 i-1$ for some natural number $n$, then \\
solution:
Let $z=x+10 i$, as $\operatorname{Im}(z)=10$ (given)

Since $z$ satisfies,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{2 z-n}{2 z+n} & =2 i-1, n \in N, \\
\therefore \quad(2 x+20 i-n) & =(2 i-1)(2 x+20 i+n) \\
\Rightarrow \quad(2 x-n)+20 i & =(-2 x-n-40)+(4 x+2 n-20) i
\end{aligned}
$$

On comparing real and imaginary parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& & 2 x-n & =-2 x-n-40 \text { and } 20=4 x+2 n-20 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 x & =-40 \text { and } 4 x+2 n=40 \\
\Rightarrow & & x & =-10 \text { and }-40+2 n=40 \\
& \text { So, } & n & =40 \text { and } x=\operatorname{Re}(z)=-10
\end{aligned}
$$

question: All the points in the set $S=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i}: \alpha \in \mathbf{R} \quad(i=\sqrt{-1})$ lie on a
options: b) straight line whose slope is -1 .
d) straight line whose slope is 1 .
solution:
Let $x+i y=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i}$

$$
\Rightarrow x+i y=\frac{(\alpha+i)^{2}}{\alpha^{2}+1}=\frac{\left(\alpha^{2}-1\right)+(2 \alpha) i}{\alpha^{2}+1}=\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1}+\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1} i
$$

On comparing real and imaginary parts, we get

$$
x=\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1} \text { and } y=\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Now, } x^{2}+y^{2}={\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1}}^{2}+{\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1}}^{2} \\
& =\frac{\alpha^{4}+1-2 \alpha^{2}+4 \alpha^{2}}{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}+y^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Which is an equation of circle with centre $(0,0)$ and radius 1 unit.

So, $S=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i} ; \alpha \in \mathbf{R}$ lies on a circle with radius 1 .

question: Let $z \in C$ be such that $|z|<1$. If $\omega=\frac{5+3 z}{5(1-z)}$, then\\
solution:
Given complex number


\begin{align*}
& \omega=\frac{5+3 z}{5(1-z)} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 5 \omega-5 \omega z=5+3 z \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(3+5 \omega) z=5 \omega-5 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|3+5 \omega||z|=\mid 5 \omega-5 \tag{i}
\end{align*}


[applying modulus both sides and $\left|z_{1} z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right|$ ]

$$
\because \quad|z|<1
$$

$\therefore|3+5 \omega|>|5 \omega-5|$

\section*{Complex Numbers}
$$
\Rightarrow \quad \omega+\frac{3}{5}>|\omega-1|
$$

Let $\omega=x+i y$, then $x+\frac{3}{5}^{2}+y^{2}>(x-1)^{2}+y^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}+\frac{9}{25}+\frac{6}{5} x>x^{2}+1-2 x$

$\Rightarrow \frac{16 x}{5}>\frac{16}{25} \Rightarrow x>\frac{1}{5} \Rightarrow 5 x>1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 5 \operatorname{Re}(\omega)>1$

question: Let $-2-\frac{1}{3} i^{3}=\frac{x+i y}{27}(i=\sqrt{-1})$, where $x$ and $y$ are real numbers, then $y-x$ equals\\
solution:
We have, $\frac{x+i y}{27}=-2-\frac{1}{3} i^{3}=\frac{-1}{3}(6+i)^{3}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \frac{x+i y}{27} & =-\frac{1}{27}\left(216+108 i+18 i^{2}+i^{3}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{27}(198+107 i)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\left[\because(a+b)^{3}=a^{3}+b^{3}+3 a^{2} b+3 a b^{2}, i^{2}=-1, i^{3}=-i\right]$

On equating real and imaginary part, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
x=-198 \text { and } y=-107 \\
\Rightarrow \quad y-x=-107+198=91
\end{gathered}
$$

question: Let $A=\theta \in-\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi: \frac{3+2 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary Then, the sum of the elements in $A$ is \\
A value of $\theta$ for which $\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary, is\\\\
solution:
Let $z=\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary. Then, we have $\operatorname{Re}(z)=0$

Now, consider $z=\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{(2+3 i \sin \theta)(1+2 i \sin \theta)}{(1-2 i \sin \theta)(1+2 i \sin \theta)} \\
& =\frac{2+4 i \sin \theta+3 i \sin \theta+6 i^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{1^{2}-(2 i \sin \theta)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2+7 i \sin \theta-6 \sin ^{2} \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta} \\
& =\frac{2-6 \sin ^{2} \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta}+i \frac{7 \sin \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta} \\
\because \quad \frac{2-6 \sin ^2 \theta}{1+4 \sin ^2 \theta} & =0 \Rightarrow 2=6 \sin ^2 \theta \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^2 \theta & =\frac{1}{3} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^2 \theta & = \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \theta & =\sin ^{-1}\left( \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)= \pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}6 i & -3 i & 1 \\ 4 & 3 i & -1 \\ 20 & 3 & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$, then
\\
solution:
Given, $\left|\begin{array}{rrr}6 i & -3 i & 1 \\ 4 & 3 i & -1 \\ 20 & 3 & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$
$\Rightarrow \quad-3 i\left|\begin{array}{crr}6 i & 1 & 1 \\ 4 & -1 & -1 \\ 20 & i & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$
$\Rightarrow \quad x+i y=0\left[\because C_2\right.$ and $C_3$ are identical $]$
$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=0, y=0
$$

question: The value of sum $\sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^{n}+i^{n+1}\right)$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}$, equals\\
solution:
$\sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^n+i^{n+1}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{13} i^n(1+i)=(1+i) \sum_{n=1}^{13} i^n$
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & (1+i)\left(i+i^2+i^3+\ldots+i^{13}\right)=(1+i)\left[\frac{i-\left(1-i^{13}\right)}{1-i}\right] \\
= & (1+i)\left[\frac{i(1-i)}{1-i}\right]=(1+i) i=i-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Alternate Solution
Since, sum of any four consecutive powers of iota is zero.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^n+i^{n+1}\right) & =\left(i+i^2+\ldots+i^{13}\right) \\
+ & \left(i^2+i^3+\ldots+i^{14}\right)=i+i^2=i-1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The smallest positive integer $n$ for which $\frac{1+i}{1-i}{ }^{n}=1$, is\\
solution:
Since, $\left(\frac{1+i}{1-i}\right)^n=1 \Rightarrow\left(\frac{1+i}{1-i} \times \frac{1+i}{1+i}\right)^n=1$
$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & \left(\frac{2 i}{2}\right)^n & =1 \\
& \Rightarrow & i^n & =1
\end{aligned}
$$

The smallest positive integer $n$ for which $i^n=1$ is 4 .

$$
\therefore \quad n=4
$$

question: The equation $|z-i|=|z-1|, i=\sqrt{-1}$, represents
options: b) the line passing through the origin with slope 1
d) the line passing through the origin with slope -1\\
solution:
Let the complex number $z=x+i y$

Also given, $|z-i|=|z-1|$

$$
\Rightarrow|x+i y-i|=|x+i y-1|
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \sqrt{x^{2}+(y-1)^{2}}=\sqrt{(x-1)^{2}+y^{2}}
$$

$$
\left[\because|z|=\sqrt{(\operatorname{Re}(z))^{2}+(\operatorname{Im}(z))^{2}}\right]
$$

On squaring both sides, we get

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}-2 y+1=x^{2}+y^{2}-2 x+1
$$

$\Rightarrow y=x$, which represents a line through the origin with slope 1 .

question: If $a>0$ and $z=\frac{(1+i)^{2}}{a-i}$, has magnitude $\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}}$, then $\bar{z}$ is equal to
solution:
The given complex number $z=\frac{(1+i)^{2}}{a-i}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{(1-1+2 i)(a+i)}{a^{2}+1} \\
& =\frac{2 i(a+i)}{a^{2}+1}=\frac{-2+2 a i}{a^{2}+1} \\
& \because \quad|z|=\sqrt{2 / 5} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{\frac{4+4 a^{2}}{\left(a^{2}+1\right)^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}} \Rightarrow \frac{2}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{4}{1+a^{2}}=\frac{2}{5} \Rightarrow a^{2}+1=10 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a^{2}=9 \Rightarrow a=3 \\
& {[\because a>0] \quad 1 \quad} \\
& \therefore \quad z=\frac{-2+6 i}{10} \\
& \text { So, } \bar{z}=\frac{-2+6 i}{10}=-\frac{1}{5}+\frac{3}{5} i \Rightarrow \bar{z}=-\frac{1}{5}-\frac{3}{5} i \\
& {[\because \text { if } z=x+i y \text {, then } \bar{z}=x-i y]}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ be two complex numbers satisfying $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$. Then, the minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is\\
solution:
Clearly $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$, represents a circle having centre $C_{1}(0,0)$ and radius $r_{1}=9$.

and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$ represents a circle having centre $C_{2}(3,4)$ and radius $r_{2}=4$.

The minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is equals to minimum distance between circles $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$.

$\because C_{1} C_{2}=\sqrt{(3-0)^{2}+(4-0)^{2}}=\sqrt{9+16}=\sqrt{25}=5$

and $\left|r_{1}-r_{2}\right| \neq 9-4\left|=5 \Rightarrow C_{1} C_{2} \# r_{1}-r_{2}\right|$

$\therefore$ Circles touches each other internally.

Hence, $\quad\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|_{\min }=0$\\

question: If $\frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}(\alpha \in R)$ is a purely imaginary number and $|z|=2$, then a value of $\alpha$ is\\
solution:
Since, the complex number $\frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}(\alpha \in R)$ is purely imaginary number, therefore

$$
\begin{array}{rlr} 
& \frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}+\frac{\bar{z}-\alpha}{\bar{z}+\alpha}=0 & {[\because \alpha \in R]} \\
\Rightarrow & z \bar{z}-\alpha \bar{z}+\alpha z-\alpha^{2}+z \bar{z}-\alpha z+\alpha \bar{z}-\alpha^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2|z|^{2}-2 \alpha^{2}=0 & {\left[\because z \bar{z}=|z|^{2}\right]} \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{2}=|z|^{2}=4 & {[|z|=2 \text { given }]} \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha= \pm 2 &
\end{array}
$$

question:
Let $z$ be a complex number such that $|z|+z=3+i$ (where $i=\sqrt{-1}$ ).

Then, $|z|$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $|z|+z=3+i$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\text { Let } & z=x+i y \\
\therefore & \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}+x+i y=3+i \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x+\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right)+i y=3+i \\
\Rightarrow & x+\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}=3 \text { and } y=1 \\
\text { Now, } & \sqrt{x^{2}+1}=3-x \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+1=9-6 x+x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 6 x=8 \Rightarrow x=\frac{4}{3} \\
\therefore & z=\frac{4}{3}+i \\
\Rightarrow & |z|=\sqrt{\frac{16}{9}+1}=\sqrt{\frac{25}{9}} \Rightarrow|z|=\frac{5}{3}
\end{array}
$$

question:
A complex number $z$ is said to be unimodular, if $|z| \neq 1$. If $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are complex numbers such that $\frac{z_{1}-2 z_{2}}{2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}}$ is unimodular and $z_{2}$ is not unimodular.

Then, the point $z_{1}$ lies on a
solution:
PLAN If $z$ is unimodular, then $|z|=1$. Also, use property of modulus i.e. $z \bar{z} \neq\left. z\right|^{2}$

Given, $z_{2}$ is not unimodular i.e. $\left|z_{2}\right| \neq 1$ and $\frac{z_{1}-2 z_{2}}{2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}}$ is unimodular.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(z_{1}-3 z_{2}\right)\left(\bar{z}_{1}-2 \bar{z}_{2}\right)=\left(2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}\right)\left(2-\bar{z}_{1} z_{2}\right) \quad\left[z \bar{z}=|z|^{2}\right] \\
& \Rightarrow\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+4\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-2 \bar{z}_{1} z_{2}-2 z_{1} \bar{z}_{2} \\
& \quad=4+\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-2 \bar{z}_{1} z_{2}-2 z_{1} \bar{z}_{2} \Rightarrow\left(\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-1\right)\left(\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}-4\right)=0 \\
& \because \quad\left|z_{2}\right| \neq 1 \\
& \therefore \quad\left|z_{1}\right|=2 \\
& \text { Let } \quad z_{1}=x+i y \Rightarrow x^{2}+y^{2}=(2)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ Point $z_{1}$ lies on a circle of radius 2 .

question: If $z$ is a complex number such that $|z| \geq 2$, then the minimum value of $\left|z+\frac{1}{2}\right|$
options: d) is strictly greater than $3 / 2$ but less than $5 / 2$

question:
Let complex numbers $\alpha$ and $1 / \bar{\alpha}$ lies on circles $\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}=r^{2}$ and $\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}=4 r^{2}$, respectively.

If $z_{0}=x_{0}+i y_{0}$ satisfies the equation $2\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}=r^{2}+2$, then $|\alpha|$ is equal to\\
Let $z$ be a complex number such that the imaginary part of $z$ is non-zero and $a=z^{2}+z+1$ is real. Then, $a$ cannot take the value\\
solution:
PLAN If $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has roots $\alpha, \beta$, then

$$
\alpha, \beta=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
$$

For roots to be real $b^{2}-4 a c \geq 0$.

Description of Situation As imaginary part of $z=x+i y$ is non-zero.

$\Rightarrow \quad y \neq 0$

Method I Let $z=x+i y$

\[
\begin{array}{lc}
\therefore & a=(x+i y)^{2}+(x+i y)+1 \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x^{2}-y^{2}+x+1-a\right)+i(2 x y+y)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x^{2}-y^{2}+x+1-a\right)+i y(2 x+1)=0 \tag{i}
\end{array}
\]

It is purely real, if $y(2 x+1)=0$

but imaginary part of $z$, i.e. $y$ is non-zero.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 2 x+1=0 \text { or } x=-1 / 2
$$

From Eq. (i), $\frac{1}{4}-y^{2}-\frac{1}{2}+1-a=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a=-y^{2}+\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow a<\frac{3}{4}
$$

Method II Here, $z^{2}+z+(1-a)=0$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & z=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1-4(1-a)}}{2 \times 1} \\
\Rightarrow & z=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{4 a-3}}{2}
\end{array}
$$

For $z$ do not have real roots, $4 a-3<0 \Rightarrow a<\frac{3}{4}$

question: Let $z=x+i y$ be a complex number where, $x$ and $y$ are integers. Then, the area of the rectangle whose vertices are the root of the equation $z \bar{z}^{3}+\bar{z} z^{3}=350$, is\\
solution:
Since,

$$
z \bar{z}\left(z^{2}+\bar{z}^{2}\right)=350
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)=350$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)=175$

Since, $x, y \in I$, the only possible case which gives integral solution, is


\begin{align*}
& x^{2}+y^{2}=25  \tag{i}\\
& x^{2}-y^{2}=7 \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


From Eqs. (i) and (ii),

$$
x^{2}=16, y^{2}=9 \Rightarrow x= \pm 4, y= \pm 3
$$

$\therefore$ Area of rectangle $=8 \times 6=48$

question: If $|z|=1$ and $z \neq \pm 1$, then all the values of $\frac{z}{1-z^{2}}$ lie on
options: a) a line not passing through the origin

question: If $w=\alpha+i \beta$, where $\beta \neq 0$ and $z \neq 1$, satisfies the condition that $\frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}$ is purely real, then the set of values of $z$ is\\
solution:
Let $z_{1}=\frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}$ be purely real $\Rightarrow \quad z_{1}=\bar{z}_{1}$

$\therefore \quad \frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}=\frac{\bar{w}-w \bar{z}}{1-\bar{z}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad w-w \bar{z}-\bar{w} z+\bar{w} z \cdot \bar{z}=\bar{w}-z \bar{w}-w \bar{z}+w z \cdot \bar{z}$

$\Rightarrow \quad(w-\bar{w})+(\bar{w}-w)|z|^{2}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad(w-\bar{w})\left(1-|z|^{2}\right)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad|z|^{2}=1 \quad$ as $w-\bar{w} \neq 0$, since $\beta \neq 0$ ]

$\Rightarrow \quad|z|=1$ and $z \neq 1$

question: If $|z|=1$ and $w=\frac{z-1}{z+1}$ (where, $z \neq-1$ ), then $\operatorname{Re}(w)$ is
For all complex numbers $z_{1}, z_{2}$ satisfying $\left|z_{1}\right|=12$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=5$, the minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is\\

If $z_{1}, z_{2}$ and $z_{3}$ are complex numbers such that $\left|z_{1}\right|=\left|z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{3}\right|=\frac{1}{z_{1}}+\frac{1}{z_{2}}+\frac{1}{z_{3}}=1$, then $\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+z_{3}\right|$ is\\
solution:
Given,

$$
\left|z_{1}\right|=\left|z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{3}\right|=1
$$

Now,

$$
\left|z_{1}\right|=1
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$$
\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}=1 \Rightarrow z_{1} \bar{z}_{1}=1
$$

Similarly,

$$
z_{2} \bar{z}_{2}=1, z_{3} \bar{z}_{3}=1
$$

Again now,

$$
\frac{1}{z_{1}}+\frac{1}{z_{2}}+\frac{1}{z_{3}}=1
$$

$\Rightarrow\left|\bar{z}_{1}+\bar{z}_{2}+\bar{z}_{3}\right|=1 \Rightarrow \overline{\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+z_{3}\right|}=1$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+z_{3}\right|=1
$$

question: For positive integers $n_{1}, n_{2}$ the value of expression $(1+i)^{n_{1}}+\left(1+i^{3}\right)^{n_{1}}+\left(1+i^{5}\right)^{n_{2}}+\left(1+i^{7}\right)^{n_{2}}$, here $i=\sqrt{-1}$ is a real number, if and only if\\
The complex numbers $\sin x+i \cos 2 x$ and $\cos x-i \sin 2 x$ are conjugate to each other, for\\
solution:
Since, $(\overline{\sin x+i \cos 2 x})=\cos x-i \sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin x-i \cos 2 x=\cos x-i \sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin x=\cos x$ and $\cos 2 x=\sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \tan x=1$ and $\tan 2 x=1$

$\Rightarrow x=\pi / 4$ and $x=\pi / 8$ which is not possible at same time.

Hence, no solution exists.

question: The points $z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}$ and $z_{4}$ in the complex plane are the vertices of a parallelogram taken in order, if and only if\\
If $z=x+i y$ and $w=(1-i z) /(z-i)$, then $|w|=1$ implies that, in the complex plane\\
options: a) $z$ lies on the imaginary axis\\
b) $z$ lies on the real axis\\
c) $z$ lies on the unit circle\\

question: The inequality $|z-4|<|z-2|$ represents the region given by\\
If $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$, then\\
solution:
Given, $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$

$$
\because \omega=\frac{-1+i \sqrt{3}}{2} \text { and } \omega^{2}=\frac{-1-i \sqrt{3}}{2}
$$

Now, $\quad \frac{\sqrt{3}+i}{2}=-i \frac{-1+i \sqrt{3}}{2}=-i \omega$

and $\quad \frac{\sqrt{3}-i}{2}=i \frac{-1-i \sqrt{3}}{2}=i \omega^{2}$

$$
\therefore \quad z=(-i \omega)^{5}+\left(i \omega^{2}\right)^{5}=-i \omega^{2}+i \omega
$$

$$
=i\left(\omega-\omega^{2}\right)=i(i \sqrt{3})=-\sqrt{3}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \operatorname{Re}(z)<0 \text { and } \operatorname{lm}(z)=0
$$

\section*{Alternate Solution}
We know that, $\quad z+\bar{z}=2 \operatorname{Re}(z)$

If

$$
z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}, \text { then }
$$

$z$ is purely real. i.e. $\operatorname{Im}(z)=0$

question: The complex numbers $z=x+i y$ which satisfy the equation $\frac{z-5 i}{z+5 i}=1$, lie on
options: c) a circle passing through the origin
solution:
Given, $\frac{z-5 i}{z+5 i}=1 \Rightarrow|z-5 i|=|z+5 i|$

$\left[\because\right.$ if $\left|z-z_{1}\right|=\left|z-z_{2}\right|$, then it is a perpendicular
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth, center]{2024_07_07_1585177dc772a224010eg-13}\\
\end{center}
bisector of $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ ]

$\therefore$ Perpendicular bisector of $(0,5)$ and $(0,-5)$ is $X$-axis.

question: If $z$ is any complex number satisfying $|z-3-2 i| \leq 2$, then the maximum value of $|2 z-6+5 i|$ is
solution:
Given, $|z-3-2 i| \leq 2$

To find minimum of $|2 z-6+5 i|$

or $2\left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right|$, using triangle inequality

i.e. ||$z_{1}|-| z_{2}|| \leq\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & & \left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right| & =\left|z-3-2 i+2 i+\frac{5}{2} i\right| \\
& =\left|(z-3-2 i)+\frac{9}{2} i\right| \\
& & \geq|| z-3-2 i\left|-\frac{9}{2}\right| \geq\left|2-\frac{9}{2}\right| \geq \frac{5}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & \left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right| \geq \frac{5}{2} \text { or }|2 z-6+5 i| \geq 5
\end{array}
$$

\section*{Topic 3 Argument of a Complex Number}

question: Let $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ be any two non-zero complex numbers such that $3\left|z_{1}\right|=4\left|z_{2}\right|$. If $z=\frac{3 z_{1}}{2 z_{2}}+\frac{2 z_{2}}{3 z_{1}}$, then\\
If $z$ is a complex number of unit modulus and argument $\theta$, then arg $\frac{1+z}{1+\bar{z}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $|z|=1, \arg z=\theta \therefore z=e^{i \theta}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad \bar{z}=e^{-i \theta} \Rightarrow \bar{z}=\frac{1}{z} \\
& \therefore \quad \arg \quad \frac{1+z}{1+\bar{z}}=\arg \frac{1+z}{1+\frac{1}{z}}=\arg (z)=\theta
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\arg (z)<0$, then $\arg (-z)-\arg (z)$ equals \\
solution:
Since, $\arg (z)<0 \Rightarrow \quad \arg (z)=-\theta$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_07_1585177dc772a224010eg-18}
\end{center}

$\Rightarrow \quad z=r \cos (-\theta)+i \sin (-\theta)$

$$
=r(\cos \theta-i \sin \theta)
$$

and $\quad-z=-r[\cos \theta-i \sin \theta]$

$$
=r[\cos (\pi-\theta)+i \sin (\pi-\theta)]
$$

$$
\therefore \quad \arg (-z)=\pi-\theta
$$

Thus, $\arg (-z)-\arg (z)$

$$
=\pi-\theta-(-\theta)=\pi
$$

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Reason $\arg (-z)-\arg z=\arg \frac{-z}{z}=\arg (-1)=\pi$ and also $\arg z-\arg (-z)=\arg \frac{z}{-z}=\arg (-1)=\pi$

question:
Let $z$ and $w$ be two complex numbers such that $|z| \leq 1$, $|w| \leq 1$ and $|z+i w|=|z-i \bar{w}|=2$, then $z$ equals
\\
solution:
Given,

$$
|z+i w|=|z-i \bar{w}|=2
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$\Rightarrow$

$\therefore z$ lies on the perpendicular bisector of the line joining $-i w$ and $-i \bar{w}$. Since, $-i \bar{w}$ is the mirror image of $-i w$ in the $X$-axis, the locus of $z$ is the $X$-axis.

Let $\quad z=x+i y$ and $y=0$.

Now, $\quad|z| \leq 1 \Rightarrow x^{2}+0^{2} \leq 1 \Rightarrow-1 \leq x \leq 1$.

$\therefore z$ may take values given in option (c).

\section*{Alternate Solution}
$$
\begin{aligned}
& |z+i w| \leq|z|+|i w|=|z|+|w| \\
& \leq 1+1=2 \\
& \therefore \quad|z+i w| \leq 2 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|z+i w|=2 \text { holds when } \\
& \arg z-\arg i w=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \arg \frac{z}{i w}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, when $|z-i \bar{w}|=2$, then $\frac{z}{\bar{w}}$ is purely imaginary

Now, given relation

$$
|z+i w|=|z-i \bar{w}|=2
$$

Put $w=i$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|z+i^{2}\right|=\left|z+i^{2}\right|=2 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|z-1|=2 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad z=-1 \quad[\because|z| \leq 1]
\end{aligned}
$$

Put $w=-i$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad\left|z-i^{2}\right|=\left|z-i^{2}\right|=2 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|z+1|=2 \Rightarrow \quad z=1 \\
& \therefore \quad z=1 \text { or }-1 \text { is the correct option. }
\end{aligned} \quad[\because|z| \leq 1]
$$

question: Let $z$ and $w$ be two non-zero complex numbers such that $|z|=|w|$ and $\arg (z)+\arg (w)=\pi$, then $z$ equals\\

If $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are two non-zero complex numbers such that $\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|+\left|z_{2}\right|$, then $\arg \left(z_{1}\right)-\arg \left(z_{2}\right)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|+\left|z_{2}\right|$

On squaring both sides, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}+2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right) \\
& =\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}+2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right)=2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right)=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \arg \left(z_{1}\right)-\arg \left(z_{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $a, b, c$ and $u, v, w$ are the complex numbers representing the vertices of two triangles such that $c=(1-r) a+r b$ and $w=(1-r) u+r v$, where $r$ is a complex number, then the two triangles\\
solution:
Since $a, b, c$ and $u, v, w$ are the vertices of two triangles.
Also,
$$ egin{array}{lr}	ext { Also, } & c=(1-r) a+r b \ 	ext { and } & w=(1-r) u+r v\end{array}$$
Consider $\left| egin{array}{lll}a & u & 1 \ b & v & 1 \ c & w & 1\end{array}ight|$
Applying $R_3 ightarrow R_3-\left\{(1-r) R_1+r R_2ight\}$
$$ egin{aligned}& =\left| egin{array}{ccc}a & u & 1 \ b & v & 1 \ c-(1-r) a-r b & w-(1-r) u-r v & 1-(1-r)-r\end{array}ight| \ & =\left| egin{array}{lll}a & u & 1 \ b & v & 1 \ 0 & 0 & 0\end{array}ight|=0 \ & \end{aligned}$$ [from Eq. (i)]

question: Let $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$. If $R(z)$ and $I(z)$ respectively denote the real and imaginary parts of $z$, then\\
solution:
Given, $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$

$\because$ Euler's form of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}=\cos \frac{\pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{\pi}{6}=e^{i(\pi / 6)} \\
& \text { and } \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}=\cos \frac{-\pi}{6}+i \sin -\frac{\pi}{6}=e^{-i \pi / 6} \\
& \text { So, } \quad z=\left(e^{i \pi / 6}\right)^{5}+\left(e^{-i \pi / 6}\right)^{5}=e^{i \frac{5 \pi}{6}}+e^{-i \frac{5 \pi}{6}} \\
& =\cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{6}+\cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}-i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{6} \\
& =2 \cos \frac{5 \pi}{6} \quad\left[\because e^{i \theta}=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta\right] \\
& \therefore \quad I(z)=0 \text { and } R(z)=-2 \cos \frac{\pi}{6}=-\sqrt{3}<0 \\
& \because \cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}=\cos \pi-\frac{\pi}{6}=-\cos \frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: A particle $P$ starts from the point $z_{0}=1+2 i$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}$. It moves first horizontally away from origin by 5 units and then vertically away from origin by 3 units to reach a point $z_{1}$. From $z_{1}$ the particle moves $\sqrt{2}$ units in the direction of the vector $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}$ and then it moves through an angle $\frac{\pi}{2}$ in anti-clockwise direction on a circle with centre at origin, to reach a point $z_{2}$. The point $z_{2}$ is given by\\

A man walks a distance of 3 units from the origin towards the North-East $\left(\mathrm{N} 45^{\circ} \mathrm{E}\right)$ direction. From there, he walks a distance of 4 units towards the North-West $\left(\mathrm{N} 45^{\circ} \mathrm{W}\right)$ direction to reach a point $P$. Then, the position of $P$ in the Argand plane is\\
If $0<\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}$ is a fixed angle. If $P=(\cos \theta, \sin \theta)$ and $Q=\{\cos (\alpha \stackrel{2}{-}), \sin (\alpha-\theta)\}$, then $Q$ is obtained from $P$ by
options: a) clockwise rotation around origin through an angle $\alpha$
b) anti-clockwise rotation around origin through an angle $\alpha$
c) reflection in the line through origin with slope $\tan \alpha$
d) reflection in the line through origin with slope $\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}$
solution:
In the Argand plane, $P$ is represented by $e^{i 0}$ and $Q$ is represented by $e^{i(\alpha-\theta)}$

Now, rotation about a line with angle $\alpha$ is given by $e^{\theta} \rightarrow e^{(\alpha-\theta)}$. Therefore, $Q$ is obtained from $P$ by reflection in the line making an angle $\alpha$ /2.
